body:
Ameba

Code style linter for Crystal

(a single-celled animal that catches food and moves about by extending fingerlike projections of protoplasm)

- [About](#about) - [Usage](#usage) - [Watch a tutorial](#watch-a-tutorial) - [Autocorrection](#autocorrection) - [Explain issues](#explain-issues) - [Run in parallel](#run-in-parallel) - [Installation](#installation) - [As a project dependency:](#as-a-project-dependency) - [OS X](#os-x) - [Docker](#docker) - [From sources](#from-sources) - [Configuration](#configuration) - [Sources](#sources) - [Rules](#rules) - [Inline disabling](#inline-disabling) - [Editors \& integrations](#editors--integrations) - [Credits \& inspirations](#credits--inspirations) - [Contributors](#contributors) ## About Ameba is a static code analysis tool for the Crystal language. It enforces a consistent [Crystal code style](https://crystal-lang.org/reference/conventions/coding_style.html), also catches code smells and wrong code constructions. See also [Roadmap](https://github.com/crystal-ameba/ameba/wiki). ## Usage Run `ameba` binary within your project directory to catch code issues: ```sh $ ameba Inspecting 107 files ...............F.....................FF.................................................................... src/ameba/formatter/flycheck_formatter.cr:6:37 [W] Lint/UnusedArgument: Unused argument `location`. If it's necessary, use `_` as an argument name to indicate that it won't be used. > source.issues.each do |issue, location| ^ src/ameba/formatter/base_formatter.cr:16:14 [W] Lint/UselessAssign: Useless assignment to variable `s` > return s += issues.size ^ src/ameba/formatter/base_formatter.cr:16:7 [Correctable] [C] Style/RedundantReturn: Redundant `return` detected > return s += issues.size ^---------------------^ Finished in 389.45 milliseconds 107 inspected, 3 failures ``` ### Watch a tutorial [ðŸŽ¬ Watch the LuckyCast showing how to use Ameba](https://luckycasts.com/videos/ameba) ### Autocorrection Rules that are marked as `[Correctable]` in the output can be automatically corrected using `--fix` flag: ```sh $ ameba --fix ``` ### Explain issues Ameba allows you to dig deeper into an issue, by showing you details about the issue and the reasoning by it being reported. To be convenient, you can just copy-paste the `PATH:line:column` string from the report and paste behind the `ameba` command to check it out. ```sh $ ameba crystal/command/format.cr:26:83 # show explanation for the issue $ ameba --explain crystal/command/format.cr:26:83 # same thing ``` ### Run in parallel Some quick benchmark results measured while running Ameba on Crystal repo: ```sh $ CRYSTAL_WORKERS=1 ameba #=> 29.11 seconds $ CRYSTAL_WORKERS=2 ameba #=> 19.49 seconds $ CRYSTAL_WORKERS=4 ameba #=> 13.48 seconds $ CRYSTAL_WORKERS=8 ameba #=> 10.14 seconds ``` ## Installation ### As a project dependency: Add this to your application's `shard.yml`: ```yaml development_dependencies: ameba: github: crystal-ameba/ameba ``` Build `bin/ameba` binary within your project directory while running `shards install`. ### OS X ```sh $ brew tap crystal-ameba/ameba $ brew install ameba ``` ### Docker Build the image: ```sh $ docker build -t ghcr.io/crystal-ameba/ameba . ``` To use the resulting image on a local source folder, mount the current (or target) directory into `/src`: ```sh $ docker run -v $(pwd):/src ghcr.io/crystal-ameba/ameba ``` Also available on GitHub: https://github.com/crystal-ameba/ameba/pkgs/container/ameba ### From sources ```sh $ git clone https://github.com/crystal-ameba/ameba && cd ameba $ make install ``` ## Configuration Default configuration file is `.ameba.yml`. It allows to configure rule properties, disable specific rules and exclude sources from the rules. Generate new file by running `ameba --gen-config`. ### Sources **List of sources to run Ameba on can be configured globally via:** - `Globs` section - an array of wildcards (or paths) to include to the inspection. Defaults to `%w[**/*.cr !lib]`, meaning it includes all project files with `*.cr` extension except those which exist in `lib` folder. - `Excluded` section - an array of wildcards (or paths) to exclude from the source list defined by `Globs`. Defaults to an empty array. In this example we define default globs and exclude `src/compiler` folder: ``` yaml Globs: - "**/*.cr" - "**/*.ecr" - "!lib" Excluded: - src/compiler ``` **Specific sources can be excluded at rule level**: ``` yaml Style/RedundantBegin: Excluded: - src/server/processor.cr - src/server/api.cr ``` ### Rules One or more rules, or a one or more group of rules can be included or excluded via command line arguments: ```sh $ ameba --only Lint/Syntax # runs only Lint/Syntax rule $ ameba --only Style,Lint # runs only rules from Style and Lint groups $ ameba --except Lint/Syntax # runs all rules except Lint/Syntax $ ameba --except Style,Lint # runs all rules except rules in Style and Lint groups ``` Or through the configuration file: ``` yaml Style/RedundantBegin: Enabled: false ``` ### Inline disabling One or more rules or one or more group of rules can be disabled using inline directives: ```crystal # ameba:disable Style/LargeNumbers time = Time.epoch(1483859302) time = Time.epoch(1483859302) # ameba:disable Style/LargeNumbers, Lint/UselessAssign time = Time.epoch(1483859302) # ameba:disable Style, Lint ``` ## Editors & integrations - Vim: [vim-crystal](https://github.com/rhysd/vim-crystal), [Ale](https://github.com/w0rp/ale) - Emacs: [ameba.el](https://github.com/crystal-ameba/ameba.el) - Sublime Text: [Sublime Linter Ameba](https://github.com/epergo/SublimeLinter-contrib-ameba) - VSCode: [vscode-crystal-ameba](https://github.com/crystal-ameba/vscode-crystal-ameba) - Codacy: [codacy-ameba](https://github.com/codacy/codacy-ameba) - GitHub Actions: [github-action](https://github.com/crystal-ameba/github-action) ## Credits & inspirations - [Crystal Language](https://crystal-lang.org) - [Rubocop](https://rubocop.org) - [Credo](http://credo-ci.org) - [Dogma](https://github.com/lpil/dogma) ## Contributors - [veelenga](https://github.com/veelenga) Vitalii Elenhaupt - creator, maintainer - [Sija](https://github.com/Sija) Sijawusz Pur Rahnama - contributor, maintainer

types.name: Ameba
types.doc:
Ameba's entry module.

To run the linter with default parameters:

```
Ameba.run
```

To configure and run it:

```
config = Ameba::Config.load
config.formatter = formatter
config.files = file_paths

Ameba.run config
```
types.summary: Ameba's entry module.

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.doc:
Initializes `Ameba::Runner` and runs it.
Can be configured via `config` parameter.

Examples:

```
Ameba.run
Ameba.run config
```
instance_methods.summary: Initializes Ameba::Runner and runs it.

types.name: Argument
types.doc:
Represents the argument of some node.
Holds the reference to the variable, thus to scope.

For example, all these vars are arguments:

```
def method(a, b, c = 10, &block)
  3.times do |i|
  end

  ->(x : Int32) { }
end
```
types.summary: Represents the argument of some node.


def.name: name
def.body:
case current_node = node
when Crystal::Var, Crystal::Arg
  current_node.name
else
  raise(ArgumentError.new("Invalid node"))
end

instance_methods.name: target_node
instance_methods.doc: Returns the target node of the variable in this assignment.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the target node of the variable in this assignment.

def.name: target_node
def.body:
case assign = node
when Crystal::Assign
  assign.target
when Crystal::OpAssign
  assign.target
when Crystal::UninitializedVar
  assign.var
when Crystal::MultiAssign
  assign.targets.find(node) do |target|
    target.is_a?(Crystal::Var) && (target.name == variable.name)
  end
else
  node
end

types.name: Branch
types.doc:
Represents the branch in Crystal code.
Branch is a part of a branchable statement.
For example, the branchable if statement contains 3 branches:

```
if a = something # --> Branch A
  a = 1          # --> Branch B
  put a if out   # --> Branch C
else
  do_something a # --> Branch D
end
```
types.summary: Represents the branch in Crystal code.

class_methods.doc:
Constructs a new branch based on the node some parent scope.

```
Branch.of(assign_node, def_node)
```
class_methods.summary: Constructs a new branch based on the node some parent scope.

class_methods.name: of
class_methods.doc:
Constructs a new branch based on the node in scope.

```
Branch.of(assign_node, scope)
```
class_methods.summary: Constructs a new branch based on the node in scope.

Creates a new branch.

constructors.summary: Creates a new branch.

instance_methods.doc: Returns `true` if this reference is the same as *other*. Invokes `same?`.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this reference is the same as other.

def.body:
if same?(other)
  return true
end
if node == other.node
else
  return false
end
if location == other.location
else
  return false
end
true

instance_methods.name: in_loop?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if current branch is in a loop, `false` - otherwise.
For example, this branch is in a loop:

```
while true
  handle_input # this branch is in a loop
  if wrong_input
    show_message # this branch is also in a loop.
  end
end
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if current branch is in a loop, false - otherwise.

types.name: Branchable
types.doc:
A generic entity to represent a branchable Crystal node.
For example, `Crystal::If`, `Crystal::Unless`, `Crystal::While`
are branchables.

```
while a > 100 # Branchable A
  if b > 2    # Branchable B
    a += 1
  end
end
```
types.summary: A generic entity to represent a branchable Crystal node.

types.name: FlowExpression
types.doc:
Represents a flow expression in Crystal code.
For example,

```
def foobar
  a = 3
  return 42 # => flow expression
  a + 1
end
```

Flow expression contains an actual node of a control expression and
a parent node, which allows easily search through the related statement
(i.e. find unreachable code)
types.summary: Represents a flow expression in Crystal code.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Creates a new flow expression.

```
FlowExpression.new(node, parent_node)
```
constructors.summary: Creates a new flow expression.

instance_methods.name: in_loop?
instance_methods.doc: Is true only if some of the nodes parents is a loop.
instance_methods.summary: Is true only if some of the nodes parents is a loop.

instance_methods.name: node
instance_methods.doc: The actual node of the flow expression.
instance_methods.summary: The actual node of the flow expression.

instance_methods.name: unreachable_nodes
instance_methods.doc:
Returns nodes which can't be reached because of a flow command inside.
For example:

```
def foobar
  a = 1
  return 42

  a + 2 # => unreachable assign node
end
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns nodes which can't be reached because of a flow command inside.

def.name: unreachable_nodes
def.body:
unreachable_nodes = [] of Crystal::ASTNode
case current_node = node
when Crystal::Expressions
  control_flow_found = false
  current_node.expressions.each do |exp|
    if control_flow_found
      unreachable_nodes << exp
    end
    control_flow_found || (control_flow_found = !(loop?(exp)) && (flow_expression?(exp, in_loop?)))
  end
when Crystal::BinaryOp
  if flow_expression?(current_node.left, in_loop?)
    unreachable_nodes << current_node.right
  end
end
unreachable_nodes

types.name: ImplicitReturnVisitor
types.doc:
AST visitor that finds nodes that are not used by their surrounding scope.

A stack is used to keep track of when a node is used, incrementing every time
something will capture its implicit (or explicit) return value, such as the
path in a class name or the value in an assign.

This also allows for passing through whether a node is captured from a nodes
parent to its children, such as from an `if` statements parent to it's body,
as the body is not used by the `if` itself, but by its parent scope.
types.summary: AST visitor that finds nodes that are not used by their surrounding scope.

instance_methods.name: visit
instance_methods.doc:
The stack is swapped out here as `Crystal::Expressions` are isolated from
their parents scope. Only the last line in an expressions node can be
captured by their parent node.
instance_methods.summary: The stack is swapped out here as Crystal::Expressions are isolated from their parents scope.

def.name: visit
def.body:
report_implicit_return(node)
last_idx = node.expressions.size - 1
swap_stack do |old_stack|
  node.expressions.each_with_index do |exp, idx|
    if exp.is_a?(Crystal::ControlExpression)
      incr_stack do
        exp.accept(self)
      end
      break
    else
      if (idx == last_idx) && old_stack.positive?
        incr_stack do
          exp.accept(self)
        end
      else
        exp.accept(self)
      end
    end
  end
end
false

def.name: visit
def.body:
report_implicit_return(node)
if (node.right.is_a?(Crystal::Call) || node.right.is_a?(Crystal::Expressions)) || node.right.is_a?(Crystal::ControlExpression)
  incr_stack do
    node.left.accept(self)
  end
else
  node.left.accept(self)
end
node.right.accept(self)
false

def.name: visit
def.body:
report_implicit_return(node)
incr_stack do
  node.obj.try(&.accept(self))
  node.args.each(&.accept(self))
  node.named_args.try(&.each(&.accept(self)))
  node.block_arg.try(&.accept(self))
  node.block.try(&.accept(self))
end
false

case

```
visitor = Ameba::AST::NodeVisitor.new(rule, source)
```

def.name: category_to_node_classes
def.body:
([] of Crystal::ASTNode.class).tap do |classes|
  if category.macro?
    classes.push(Crystal::Macro, Crystal::MacroExpression, Crystal::MacroIf, Crystal::MacroFor)
  end
end

def.name: new
def.body:
_ = allocate
_.initialize(rule, source, skip: skip)
if _.responds_to?(:finalize)
  ::GC.add_finalizer(_)
end

instance_methods.name: visit
instance_methods.doc:

scope = @current_scope
variable = scope.find_variable(node.name)
case
when scope.arg?(node)
  scope.add_argument(node)
when variable.nil? && @current_assign
  scope.add_variable(node)
when variable
  reference = variable.reference(node, scope)
  if @current_assign.is_a?(Crystal::OpAssign) || !(reference.target_of?(@current_assign))
    variable.reference_assignments!
  end
end

def.body:
if exp = node.exp
else

instance_methods.name: flow_command?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if node is a flow command, `false` otherwise.
Node represents a flow command if it is a control expression,
or special call node that interrupts execution (i.e. raise, exit, abort).
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if node is a flow command, false otherwise.

def.name: flow_command?
def.body:
case node
when Crystal::Return
  true
when Crystal::Break, Crystal::Next
  in_loop
when Crystal::Call
  ((raise?(node)) || (exit?(node))) || (abort?(node))
else
  false
end

instance_methods.name: flow_expression?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if node is a flow expression, `false` if not.
Node represents a flow expression if it is full-filled by a flow command.

For example, this node is a flow expression, because each branch contains
a flow command `return`:

```
if a > 0
  return :positive
elsif a < 0
  return :negative
else
  return :zero
end
```

This node is a not a flow expression:

```
if a > 0
  return :positive
end
```

That's because not all branches return(i.e. `else` is missing).
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if node is a flow expression, false if not.

def.name: flow_expression?
def.body:
if flow_command?(node, in_loop)
  return true
end
case node
when Crystal::If, Crystal::Unless
  flow_expressions?([node.then, node.else], in_loop)
when Crystal::BinaryOp
  flow_expression?(node.left, in_loop)
when Crystal::Case
  flow_expressions?([node.whens, node.else].flatten, in_loop)
when Crystal::ExceptionHandler
  flow_expressions?([node.else || node.body, node.rescues].flatten, in_loop)
when Crystal::While, Crystal::Until
  flow_expression?(node.body, in_loop)
when Crystal::Rescue, Crystal::When
  flow_expression?(node.body, in_loop)
when Crystal::Expressions
  node.expressions.any? do |exp|
    flow_expression?(exp, in_loop)
  end
else
  false
end

instance_methods.doc: Returns `true` if current `node` is a literal, `false` otherwise.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if current node is a literal, false otherwise.

instance_methods.doc: Returns `true` if node represents a loop.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if node represents a loop.

def.name: loop?
def.body:
case node
when Crystal::While, Crystal::Until
  true
when Crystal::Call
  ((node.name == "loop") && (node.args.size == 0)) && node.obj.nil?
else
  false
end

Returns `nil` if *node* does not contain a name.

NOTE: Use this instead of `Crystal::Call#name_end_location` to avoid an
      off-by-one error.
instance_methods.summary: Returns nil if node does not contain a name.

def.name: name_end_location
def.body:
if loc = name_location(node)
else
  return
end
if (size = name_size(node)).zero?
  return
end
loc.adjust(column_number: size - 1)

instance_methods.name: name_location
instance_methods.doc: Returns `nil` if *node* does not contain a name.
instance_methods.summary: Returns nil if node does not contain a name.

def.name: name_location
def.body:
if loc = node.name_location
  return loc
end
if node.is_a?(Crystal::TypeDeclaration) || node.is_a?(Crystal::UninitializedVar)
  return node.var.location
end
if (node.responds_to?(:name)) && (name = node.name)
else
  return
end
if name.is_a?(Crystal::ASTNode)
else
  return
end
name.location

instance_methods.name: name_size
instance_methods.doc: Returns zero if *node* does not contain a name.
instance_methods.summary: Returns zero if node does not contain a name.

def.name: name_size
def.body:
if (size = node.name_size).zero?
else
  return size
end
if (node.responds_to?(:name)) && (name = node.name)
else
  return 0
end
case name
when Crystal::ASTNode
  name.name_size
when Crystal::Token::Kind
  name.to_s.size
else
  name.size
end

instance_methods.doc:
Returns a source code for the current node.
This method uses `node.location` and `node.end_location`
to determine and cut a piece of source of the node.
instance_methods.summary: Returns a source code for the current node.

def.name: node_source
def.body:
loc, end_loc = node.location, node.end_location
if loc && end_loc
else
  return
end
source_between(loc, end_loc, code_lines)

instance_methods.doc: Returns `true` if node has a `:nodoc:` annotation as the first line.

def.name: nodoc?
def.body:
if node.responds_to?(:doc)
else
  return false
end
if doc = node.doc.presence
else
  return false
end
doc.lines.first?.try(&.strip) == ":nodoc:"

instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if current `node` is a `Crystal::Path`
matching given *name*, `false` otherwise.

instance_methods.doc: Returns `true` if node represents `raise` method call.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if node represents raise method call.

instance_methods.name: source_between
instance_methods.doc: Returns the source code from *loc* to *end_loc* (inclusive).
instance_methods.summary: Returns the source code from loc to end_loc (inclusive).

def.name: source_between
def.body:
line, column = loc.line_number - 1, loc.column_number - 1
end_line, end_column = end_loc.line_number - 1, end_loc.column_number - 1
node_lines = code_lines[line..end_line]
first_line, last_line = node_lines[0]?, node_lines[-1]?
if first_line.nil? || last_line.nil?
  return
end
if first_line.size < column
  return
end
node_lines[0] = first_line.sub(0...column, "")
if line == end_line
  end_column = end_column - column
  last_line = node_lines[0]
end
if last_line.size < (end_column + 1)
  return
end
node_lines[-1] = last_line.sub((end_column + 1)...last_line.size, "")
node_lines.join('\n')

instance_methods.name: captured_by_block?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if the current var is referenced in
in the block. For example this variable is captured
by block:

```
a = 1
3.times { |i| a = a + i }
```

And this variable is not captured by block.

```
i = 1
3.times { |i| i + 1 }
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if the current var is referenced in in the block.

def.name: captured_by_block?
def.body:
scope.inner_scopes.each do |inner_scope|
  if inner_scope.block? && (inner_scope.references?(self, check_inner_scopes: false))
    return true
  end
  if captured_by_block?(inner_scope)
    return true
  end
end
false

def.body:
var_location, node_location = location, node.location
if var_location && node_location
else
  return
end
(var_location.line_number < node_location.line_number) || ((var_location.line_number == node_location.line_number) && var_location.column_number < node_location.column_number)

```

variable.reference_assignments!
```
instance_methods.summary: Reference variable's assignments.

def.name: reference_assignments!
def.body:
consumed_branches = Set(Branch).new
assignments.reverse_each do |assignment|
  if assignment.branch.in?(consumed_branches)
    next
  end
  assignment.referenced = true
  if branch = assignment.branch
  else
    break
  end
  consumed_branches << branch
end

instance_methods.name: target_of?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if the variable is a target (on the left) of the assignment,
`false` otherwise.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if the variable is a target (on the left) of the assignment, false otherwise.

def.name: target_of?
def.body:
case assign
when Crystal::Assign
  eql?(assign.target)
when Crystal::OpAssign
  eql?(assign.target)
when Crystal::MultiAssign
  assign.targets.any? do |target|
    eql?(target)
  end
when Crystal::UninitializedVar
  eql?(assign.var)
else
  false
end

instance_methods.name: used_in_macro?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if current variable potentially referenced in a macro,
`false` if not.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if current variable potentially referenced in a macro, false if not.

def.name: used_in_macro?
def.body:
scope.inner_scopes.each do |inner_scope|
  if (MacroReferenceFinder.new(inner_scope.node, node.name)).references?
    return true
  end
end
if (MacroReferenceFinder.new(scope.node, node.name)).references?
  return true
end
if (outer_scope = scope.outer_scope) && (used_in_macro?(outer_scope))
  return true
end
false

types.name: Config

constants.name: AVAILABLE_FORMATTERS
constants.value: {progress: Formatter::DotFormatter, todo: Formatter::TODOFormatter, flycheck: Formatter::FlycheckFormatter, silent: Formatter::BaseFormatter, disabled: Formatter::DisabledFormatter, json: Formatter::JSONFormatter, "github-actions": Formatter::GitHubActionsFormatter}

types.doc:
A configuration entry for `Ameba::Runner`.

Config can be loaded from configuration YAML file and adjusted.

```
config = Config.load
config.formatter = my_formatter
```

By default config loads `.ameba.yml` file located in a current
working directory.

If it cannot be found until reaching the root directory, then it will be
searched for in the userâ€™s global config locations, which consists of a
dotfile or a config file inside the XDG Base Directory specification.

- `~/.ameba.yml`
- `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/ameba/config.yml` (expands to `~/.config/ameba/config.yml`
  if `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME` is not set)

If both files exist, the dotfile will be selected.

As an example, if Ameba is invoked from inside `/path/to/project/lib/utils`,
then it will use the config as specified inside the first of the following files:

- `/path/to/project/lib/utils/.ameba.yml`
- `/path/to/project/lib/.ameba.yml`
- `/path/to/project/.ameba.yml`
- `/path/to/.ameba.yml`
- `/path/.ameba.yml`
- `/.ameba.yml`
- `~/.ameba.yml`
- `~/.config/ameba/config.yml`
types.summary: A configuration entry for Ameba::Runner.

class_methods.name: load
class_methods.doc:
Loads YAML configuration file by `path`.

```
config = Ameba::Config.load
```
class_methods.summary: Loads YAML configuration file by path.

def.name: load
def.body:
begin
  Colorize.enabled = colors
  content = if skip_reading_config
    "{}"
  else
    (read_config(path)) || "{}"
  end
  Config.new(YAML.parse(content))
rescue e
  raise("Unable to load config file: #{e.message}")
end

def.name: update_rules
def.body:
names.try(&.each do |name|
  if rules = @rule_groups[name]?
    rules.each do |rule|
      rule.enabled = enabled
      rule.excluded = excluded
    end
  else
    update_rule(name, enabled, excluded)
  end
end)

def.body:

  raise(ArgumentError.new("Mismatching filenames:\n  #{@filename}\n  #{offset.filename}"))
end
if offset.line_number == 1

else
  self.class.new(@filename, (@line_number + offset.line_number) - 1, offset.column_number)
end

def.name: finished
def.body:
output << "Disabled rules using inline directives:\n\n"
sources.each do |source|
  source.issues.each do |issue|
    if issue.disabled?
    else
      next
    end
    if loc = issue.location
    else
      next
    end
    output << ("#{source.path}:#{loc.line_number}".colorize(:cyan))
    output << " #{issue.rule.name}\n"
  end
end

types.name: DotFormatter
types.doc:
A formatter that shows a progress of inspection in a terminal using dots.
It is similar to Crystal's dot formatter for specs.
types.summary: A formatter that shows a progress of inspection in a terminal using dots.

instance_methods.name: finished
instance_methods.doc: Reports a message when inspection is finished.
instance_methods.summary: Reports a message when inspection is finished.

def.name: finished
def.body:
output.flush
output << "\n\n"
show_affected_code = !config[:without_affected_code]?
failed_sources = sources.reject(&.valid?)
failed_sources.each do |source|
  source.issues.each do |issue|
    if issue.disabled?
      next
    end
    if (location = issue.location).nil?
      next
    end
    output.print(location.colorize(:cyan))
    if issue.correctable?
      if config[:autocorrect]?
        output.print(" [Corrected]".colorize(:green))
      else
        output.print(" [Correctable]".colorize(:yellow))
      end
    end
    output.puts
    output.puts(("[%s] %s: %s" % {issue.rule.severity.symbol, issue.rule.name, issue.message}).colorize(issue.rule.severity.color))
    if show_affected_code && (code = affected_code(issue))
      output << (code.colorize(:default))
    end
    output.puts
  end
end
output.puts(finished_in_message(@started_at, Time.monotonic))
output.puts(final_message(sources, failed_sources))

A corresponding source is passed as an argument.

WARNING: This method needs to be MT safe
instance_methods.summary: Callback that indicates when source inspection is finished.

def.name: source_finished
def.body:
source.issues.each do |issue|
  if issue.disabled?
    next
  end
  if issue.correctable? && config[:autocorrect]?
    next
  end
  if loc = issue.location
  else
    next
  end
  @mutex.synchronize do
    output.printf("%s:%d:%d: %s: [%s] %s\n", source.path, loc.line_number, loc.column_number, issue.rule.severity.symbol, issue.rule.name, issue.message.gsub('\n', " "))
  end
end

instance_methods.name: source_finished
instance_methods.doc: Reports a result of the inspection of a corresponding source.
instance_methods.summary: Reports a result of the inspection of a corresponding source.

def.name: source_finished
def.body:
source.issues.each do |issue|
  if issue.disabled?
    next
  end
  @mutex.synchronize do
    output << "::"
    output << (command_name(issue.rule.severity))
    output << " "
    output << "file="
    output << (escape_property(source.path))
    if location = issue.location
      output << ",line="
      output << location.line_number
      output << ",col="
      output << location.column_number
    end
    if end_location = issue.end_location
      output << ",endLine="
      output << end_location.line_number
      output << ",endColumn="
      output << end_location.column_number
    end
    output << ",title="
    output << (escape_property(issue.rule.name))
    output << "::"
    output << (escape_data(issue.message))
    output << "\n"
  end
end

instance_methods.summary: Reports a message when inspection is finished.

def.name: finished
def.body:
super(sources)
issues = sources.flat_map(&.issues)
if issues.any? do |issue|
  !issue.disabled?
end
else
  @output.puts("No issues found. File is not generated.")
  return
end
if issues.any?(&.syntax?)
  @output.puts("Unable to generate TODO file. Please fix syntax issues.")
  return
end
generate_todo_config(issues)
@output.puts("Created #{@config_path}")

else

instance_methods.name: affected_code
instance_methods.args_string: (code, location, end_location = nil, context_lines = 0, max_length = 120, ellipsis = " ...", prompt = "> ")
instance_methods.args_html: (code, location, end_location = nil, context_lines = 0, max_length = 120, ellipsis = " ...", prompt = "> ")

def.name: affected_code
def.body:
lines = code.split('\n')
lineno, column = location.line_number, location.column_number
if affected_line = lines[lineno - 1]?.presence
else
  return
end
if column < max_length
  affected_line = trim(affected_line, max_length, ellipsis)
end
position = prompt.size + column
position = position - 1
show_context = context_lines > 0
if show_context
  pre_context, post_context = context(lines, lineno, context_lines)
else
  affected_line_size, affected_line = affected_line.size, affected_line.lstrip
  indent_size_diff = affected_line_size - affected_line.size
  if column > indent_size_diff
    position = position - indent_size_diff
  end
end
String.build do |str|
  if show_context
    pre_context.try(&.each do |line|
      line = trim(line, max_length, ellipsis)
      str << prompt
      str.puts(line.colorize(:dark_gray))
    end)
  end
  str << prompt
  str.puts(affected_line.colorize(:white))
  str << (" " * position)
  str << ("^".colorize(:yellow))
  if end_location
    end_lineno = end_location.line_number
    end_column = end_location.column_number
    if (end_lineno == lineno) && end_column > column
      end_position = end_column - column
      end_position = end_position - 1
      str << (("-" * end_position).colorize(:dark_gray))
      str << ("^".colorize(:yellow))
    end
  end
  str.puts
  if show_context
    post_context.try(&.each do |line|
      line = trim(line, max_length, ellipsis)
      str << prompt
      str.puts(line.colorize(:dark_gray))
    end)
  end
end

def.name: context
def.body:
pre_context, post_context = [] of ::String, [] of ::String
lines.each_with_index do |line, i|
  case i + 1
  when (lineno - context_lines)...lineno
    pre_context << line
  when (lineno + 1)..(lineno + context_lines)
    post_context << line
  end
end
if remove_empty
  while pre_context.first?.try(&.blank?)
    pre_context.shift
  end
  while post_context.last?.try(&.blank?)
    post_context.pop
  end
end
{pre_context, post_context}

def.name: to_human
def.body:
total_milliseconds = span.total_milliseconds
if total_milliseconds < 1
  return "#{(span.total_milliseconds * 1000).round.to_i} microseconds"
end
total_seconds = span.total_seconds
if total_seconds < 1
  return "#{span.total_milliseconds.round(2)} milliseconds"
end
if total_seconds < 60
  return "#{total_seconds.round(2)} seconds"
end
minutes = span.minutes
seconds = span.seconds
"#{minutes}:#{seconds < 10 ? "0" : ""}#{seconds} minutes"

def.name: trim
def.body:
if (str.size - ellipsis.size) > max_length
  str = str[0, max_length]
  if str.size > ellipsis.size
    str = str[0...(-ellipsis.size)] + ellipsis
  end
end
str

instance_methods.name: expand
instance_methods.doc:
Expands globs. Globs can point to files or even directories.

```
expand(["spec/*.cr", "src"]) # => all files in src folder + first level specs
```
instance_methods.summary: Expands globs.

def.name: expand
def.body:
globs.flat_map do |glob|
  if File.directory?(glob)
    ext = ".cr"
    Ameba.ecr_supported? do
      ext = ".{cr,ecr}"
    end
    glob = glob + "/**/*#{ext}"
  end
  Dir[glob]
end.uniq!.select! do |path|
  File.file?(path)
end

```
find_files_by_globs(["**/*.cr", "!lib"])
```

instance_methods.name: location_disabled?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if current location is disabled for a particular rule,
`false` otherwise.

Location is disabled in two cases:
  1. The line of the location ends with a comment directive.
  2. The line above the location is a comment directive.

For example, here are two examples of disabled location:

```
# ameba:disable Style/LargeNumbers
Time.epoch(1483859302)

Time.epoch(1483859302) # ameba:disable Style/LargeNumbers
```

But here are examples which are not considered as disabled location:

```
# ameba:disable Style/LargeNumbers
#
Time.epoch(1483859302)

if use_epoch? # ameba:disable Style/LargeNumbers
  Time.epoch(1483859302)
end
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if current location is disabled for a particular rule, false otherwise.

def.name: location_disabled?
def.body:
if rule.name.in?(Rule::SPECIAL)
  return false
end
if line_number = location.try do |__arg0|
  __arg0.line_number.try(&.-(1))
end
else
  return false
end
if line = lines[line_number]?
else
  return false
end
(line_disabled?(line, rule)) || (((line_number > 0 && (prev_line = lines[line_number - 1])) && (comment?(prev_line))) && (line_disabled?(prev_line, rule)))

instance_methods.name: parse_inline_directive
instance_methods.doc:
Parses inline comment directive. Returns a tuple that consists of
an action and parsed rules if directive found, nil otherwise.

```
line = "# ameba:disable Rule1, Rule2"
directive = parse_inline_directive(line)
directive[:action] # => "disable"
directive[:rules]  # => ["Rule1", "Rule2"]
```

It ignores the directive if it is commented out.

```
line = "# # ameba:disable Rule1, Rule2"
parse_inline_directive(line) # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Parses inline comment directive.

def.name: run
def.body:
rules = rules.to_h do |rule|
  name = rule.name.split('/')
  name = "%s/%s" % {(name[0...-1].join('/')).colorize(:light_gray), name.last.colorize(:white)}
  {name, rule}
end
longest_name = rules.max_of() do |__arg0|
  __arg0.first.size
end
rules.group_by() do |__arg1|
  __arg1.last.group
end.each do |group, group_rules|
  output.puts("â€” %s" % (group.colorize(:light_blue)).underline)
  output.puts
  group_rules.each do |name, rule|
    output.puts("  %s  [%s]    %s    %s" % {rule.enabled? ? ENABLED_MARK : DISABLED_MARK, rule.severity.symbol.to_s.colorize(:green), name.ljust(longest_name), rule.description.colorize(:dark_gray)})
  end
  output.puts
end
output.puts("Total rules: %s / %s enabled" % {rules.size.to_s.colorize(:light_blue), rules.count() do |__arg2|
  __arg2.last.enabled?
end.to_s.colorize(:light_blue)})

def.name: run
def.body:
output_title("Rule info")
info = "Name:           %s\nSeverity:       %s\nEnabled:        %s\nSince version:  %s"
output_paragraph(info % {rule.name.colorize(:magenta), rule.severity.to_s.colorize(rule.severity.color), rule.enabled? ? ENABLED_MARK : DISABLED_MARK, (rule.since_version.try(&.to_s) || "N/A").colorize(:white)})
if rule_description = colorize_code_fences(rule.description)
  output_title("Description")
  output_paragraph(rule_description)
end
if rule_doc = colorize_code_fences(rule.class.parsed_doc)
  output_title("Detailed description")
  output_paragraph(rule_doc)
end

def.name: run
def.body:
missing_version = SemanticVersion.new(0, 0, 0)
versions = rules.sort_by do |rule|
  rule.since_version || missing_version
end.group_by(&.since_version)
first = true
versions.each do |version, version_rules|
  if verbose
    if first
    else
      output.puts
    end
    if version
      output.puts("- %s" % (version.to_s.colorize(:green)))
    else
      output.puts("- %s" % ("N/A".colorize(:dark_gray)))
    end
    version_rules.map(&.name).sort!.each do |name|
      output.puts("  - %s" % (name.colorize(:dark_gray)))
    end
  else
    if version
      output.puts("- %s" % (version.to_s.colorize(:green)))
    end
  end
  first = false
end

```
Ameba::Rule.rules # => [Rule1, Rule2, ....]
```

types.name: Base
types.doc:
Represents a base of all rules. In other words, all rules
inherits from this struct:

```
class MyRule < Ameba::Rule::Base
  def test(source)
    if invalid?(source)
      issue_for line, column, "Something wrong."
    end
  end

  private def invalid?(source)
    # ...
  end
end
```

Enforces rules to implement an abstract `#test` method which
is designed to test the source passed in. If source has issues
that are tested by this rule, it should add an issue.
types.summary: Represents a base of all rules.

instance_methods.doc: Returns `false` (other can only be a `Value` here).
instance_methods.summary: Returns false (other can only be a Value here).

instance_methods.doc:
A convenient addition to `#test` method that does the same
but returns a passed in `source` as an addition.

```
source = MyRule.new.catch(source)
source.valid?
```
instance_methods.summary: A convenient addition to #test method that does the same but returns a passed in source as an addition.

```
MyGroup::MyRule.new.group # => "MyGroup"
```

instance_methods.name: hash
instance_methods.doc:
Generates an `UInt64` hash value for this object.

This method must have the property that `a == b` implies `a.hash == b.hash`.

The hash value is used along with `==` by the `Hash` class to determine if two objects
reference the same hash key.

Subclasses must not override this method. Instead, they must define `hash(hasher)`,
though usually the macro `def_hash` can be used to generate this method.
instance_methods.summary: Generates an UInt64 hash value for this object.

types.name: DocumentationAdmonition
types.doc:
A rule that reports documentation admonitions.

Optionally, these can fail at an appropriate time.

```
def get_user(id)
  # TODO(2024-04-24) Fix this hack when the database migration is complete
  if id < 1_000_000
    v1_api_call(id)
  else
    v2_api_call(id)
  end
end
```

`TODO` comments are used to remind yourself of source code related things.

The premise here is that `TODO` should be dealt with in the near future
and are therefore reported by Ameba.

`FIXME` comments are used to indicate places where source code needs fixing.

The premise here is that `FIXME` should indeed be fixed as soon as possible
and are therefore reported by Ameba.

YAML configuration example:

```
Documentation/DocumentationAdmonition:
  Enabled: true
  Admonitions: [TODO, FIXME, BUG]
  Timezone: UTC
```
types.summary: A rule that reports documentation admonitions.

```
    end
  end
end

MyRule.parsed_doc # => "This is a test rule.\nDoes nothing."
```

def.name: test
def.body:
(Tokenizer.new(source)).run do |token|
  if token.type.comment?
  else
    next
  end
  if doc = token.value.to_s
  else
    next
  end
  pattern = /^#\s*(?<admonition>#{Regex.union(admonitions)})(?:\((?<context>.+?)\))?(?:\W+|$)/m
  matches = doc.scan(pattern)
  matches.each do |match|
    admonition = match["admonition"]
    end_location = token.location.adjust(column_number: admonition.size + 1)
    token_location = {token.location, end_location}
    begin
      case expr = match["context"]?.presence
      when /\A\d{4}-\d{2}-\d{2}\Z/
        date = Time.parse($~[0], "%F", location)
        issue_for_date(source, token_location, admonition, date)
      when /\A\d{4}-\d{2}-\d{2} \d{2}:\d{2}(:\d{2})?\Z/
        date = Time.parse($~[0], "%F #{$~[1]?.presence ? "%T" : "%R"}", location)
        issue_for_date(source, token_location, admonition, date)
      else
        issue_for(*token_location, MSG % admonition)
      end
    rescue ex
      issue_for(*token_location, MSG_ERR % {admonition, "#{ex}: #{expr.inspect}"})
    end
  end
end

  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
source_lines = source.lines
if source_lines.empty?
  return
end
last_source_line = source_lines.last
source_lines_size = source_lines.size
if (source_lines_size == 1) && last_source_line.empty?
  return
end
last_line_empty = last_source_line.empty?
if source_lines_size.zero? || ((source_lines.last(2)).join.presence && last_line_empty)
  return
end
if last_line_empty
  issue_for({source_lines_size, 1}, MSG)
else
  issue_for({source_lines_size, 1}, MSG_FINAL_NEWLINE) do |corrector|
    corrector.insert_before({source_lines_size + 1, 1}, '\n')
  end
end

types.name: AmbiguousAssignment
types.doc:
This rule checks for mistyped shorthand assignments.

This is considered invalid:

```
x = -y
x = +y
x = !y
```

And this is valid:

```
x -= y # or x = -y
x += y # or x = +y
x != y # or x = !y
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/AmbiguousAssignment:
  Enabled: true
```

types.name: BadDirective
types.doc:
A rule that reports incorrect comment directives for Ameba.

For example, the user can mistakenly add a directive
to disable a rule that even doesn't exist:

```
# ameba:disable BadRuleName

end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/BadDirective:
```

types.name: ComparisonToBoolean
types.doc:
A rule that disallows comparison to booleans.

For example, these are considered invalid:

```
foo == true
bar != false
false === baz
```

This is because these expressions evaluate to `true` or `false`, so you
could get the same result by using either the variable directly,
or negating the variable.

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/ComparisonToBoolean:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows comparison to booleans.


For example, these are considered invalid:

def.name: new
def.body:
if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
if node.name.in?(OP_NAMES)
else
  return
end
if node.args.size == 1
else
  return
end
arg, obj = node.args.first, node.obj
case
when arg.is_a?(Crystal::BoolLiteral)
  bool, exp = arg, obj
when obj.is_a?(Crystal::BoolLiteral)
  bool, exp = obj, arg
end
if bool && exp
else
  return
end
if exp_code = node_source(exp, source.lines)
else
  return
end
not = case node.name
when "==", "==="
  !bool.value
when "!="
  bool.value
end
if not
  exp_code = "!#{exp_code}"
end
issue_for(node, MSG) do |corrector|
  corrector.replace(node, exp_code)
end

```
when Symbol
  do_something_else
```

def.body:
node.whens.each_with_object(Set(String).new) do |when_node, processed_conditions|
  when_node.conds.each do |cond|
    cond_s = cond.to_s
    if processed_conditions.includes?(cond_s)
      issue_for(cond, MSG)
    else
      processed_conditions << cond_s
    end
  end
end

types.name: EmptyEnsure
types.doc:
A rule that disallows empty ensure statement.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
def some_method
  do_some_stuff
ensure
end

begin
  do_some_stuff
ensure
end
```

And it should be written as this:

```
def some_method
  do_some_stuff
ensure
  do_something_else
end

begin
  do_some_stuff
ensure
  do_something_else
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/EmptyEnsure
  Enabled: true
```

types.doc:
A rule that verifies syntax formatting according to the
Crystal's built-in formatter.

For example, this syntax is invalid:

    def foo(a,b,c=0)

      a+b+c
    end

And should be properly written:

    def foo(a, b, c = 0)
      # foobar
      a + b + c
    end

```
Lint/Formatting:
  Enabled: true
  FailOnError: false
```

def.name: new

  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
begin
  source_code = source.code
  source_lines = source_code.lines
  if source_lines.empty?
    return
  end
  result = Crystal.format(source_code, source.path)
  if result == source_code
    return
  end
  end_location = {source_lines.size, source_lines.last.size + 1}
  issue_for(LOCATION, MSG) do |corrector|
    corrector.replace(LOCATION, end_location, result)
  end
rescue ex : Crystal::SyntaxException
  if fail_on_error?
    issue_for({ex.line_number, ex.column_number}, MSG_ERROR % ex.message)
  end
rescue ex
  if fail_on_error?
    issue_for(LOCATION, MSG_ERROR % ex.message)
  end
end

types.name: LiteralInCondition
types.doc:
A rule that disallows useless conditional statements that contain a literal
in place of a variable or predicate function.

This is because a conditional construct with a literal predicate will
always result in the same behavior at run time, meaning it can be
replaced with either the body of the construct, or deleted entirely.

This is considered invalid:

```
if "something"
  :ok
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/LiteralInCondition:
  Enabled: true
```

def.name: new
def.body:
if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
if node.name.in?(OP_NAMES)
else
  return
end
if (obj = node.obj) && (arg = node.args.first?)
else
  return
end
obj_is_literal, obj_is_static = literal_kind?(obj)
arg_is_literal, arg_is_static = literal_kind?(arg)
if obj_is_literal && arg_is_literal
else
  return
end
if obj.to_s == arg.to_s
else
  return
end
is_dynamic = !obj_is_static || !arg_is_static
what = case node.name
when "==="
  "the same"
when "=="
  "true"
when "!="
  "false"
end
issue_for(node, (is_dynamic ? MSG_LIKELY : MSG) % what)

```
%w[Alice Bob].find!(&.chars.any?(&.in?('o', 'b')))
```

```
Lint/NotNilAfterNoBang:
  Enabled: true
```

def.name: new
def.body:
if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
if (node.name == "not_nil!") && node.args.empty?
else
  return
end
if (obj = node.obj).is_a?(Crystal::Call)
else
  return
end
if obj.name.in?(obj.block ? BLOCK_CALL_NAMES : CALL_NAMES)
else
  return
end
if name_location = name_location(obj)
else
  return
end
if name_location_end = name_end_location(obj)
else
  return
end
if end_location = name_end_location(node)
else
  return
end
msg = MSG % {obj.name, obj.name}
issue_for(name_location, end_location, msg) do |corrector|
  corrector.insert_after(name_location_end, '!')
  corrector.remove_trailing(node, {{ ".not_nil!".size }})
end

types.name: PercentArrays

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Symbols `%s` may be unwanted in `%s` array literals"

types.doc:
A rule that disallows some unwanted symbols in percent string and symbol array literals.

For example, this is usually written by mistake:

```
%w["one", "two"]
%i[:one, :two]
```

And the expected example is:

```
%w[one two]
%i[one two]
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/PercentArrays:
  Enabled: true
  StringArrayUnwantedSymbols: ',"'
  SymbolArrayUnwantedSymbols: ',:'
```

def.name: new
def.body:
if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
issue = start_token = nil
(Tokenizer.new(source)).run do |token|
  case token.type
  when .string_array_start?, .symbol_array_start?
    start_token = token.dup
  when .string?
    if (_start = start_token) && !issue
      issue = array_entry_invalid?(token.value.to_s, _start.raw)
    end
  when .string_array_end?
    if (_start = start_token) && (_issue = issue)
      issue_for(_start.location, _start.location.adjust(column_number: 1), _issue)
    end
    issue = start_token = nil
  end
end

```
collection.each do |e|
  # ...
end
```

def.name: test
def.body:
args, block = node.args, node.block
if block.nil? || args.size > 1
  return
end
if with_index_arg?(block)
  return
end
case node.name
when "with_index"
  report(source, node, "Remove redundant with_index")
when "each_with_index"
  report(source, node, "Use each instead of each_with_index")
end

types.name: RedundantWithObject

```

end
```

and it should be written as follows:

```
collection.each do |e|
  # ...
end
```

types.name: RequireParentheses

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Use parentheses in the method call to avoid confusion about precedence"

types.doc:
A rule that disallows method calls with at least one argument, where no
parentheses are used around the argument list, and a logical operator
(`&&` or `||`) is used within the argument list.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
if foo.includes? "bar" || foo.includes? "baz"
  # ...
end
```

And need to be written as:

```
if foo.includes?("bar") || foo.includes?("baz")
  # ...
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/RequireParentheses:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows method calls with at least one argument, where no parentheses are used around the argument list, and a logical operator (&& or ||) is used within the argument list.

def.name: test
def.body:
if ((node.args.empty? || node.has_parentheses?) || (node.name.ends_with?('='))) || (node.name.in?(ALLOWED_CALL_NAMES))
  return
end
node.args.each do |arg|
  if arg.is_a?(Crystal::BinaryOp)
  else
    next
  end
  if (right = arg.right).is_a?(Crystal::Call)
  else
    next
  end
  if right.args.empty?
    next
  end
  issue_for(node, MSG)
end

types.name: ShadowedArgument

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Argument `%s` is assigned before it is used"

types.doc:
A rule that disallows shadowed arguments.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
do_something do |foo|
  foo = 1 # shadows block argument
  foo
end

def do_something(foo)
  foo = 1 # shadows method argument
  foo
end
```

and it should be written as follows:

```
do_something do |foo|
  foo = foo + 42
  foo
end

def do_something(foo)
  foo = foo + 42
  foo
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/ShadowedArgument:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows shadowed arguments.

types.name: ShadowedException
types.doc:
A rule that disallows a rescued exception that get shadowed by a
less specific exception being rescued before a more specific
exception is rescued.

For example, this is invalid:

```
begin
  do_something
rescue Exception
  handle_exception
rescue ArgumentError
  handle_argument_error_exception
end
```

And it has to be written as follows:

```
begin
  do_something
rescue ArgumentError
  handle_argument_error_exception
rescue Exception
  handle_exception
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/ShadowedException:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows a rescued exception that get shadowed by a less specific exception being rescued before a more specific exception is rescued.

types.name: ShadowingOuterLocalVar
types.doc:
A rule that disallows the usage of the same name as outer local variables

```
  end
end
```

and should be written as:

```
def some_method
  foo = 1

  3.times do |bar|
  end
end
```

types.name: SharedVarInFiber
types.doc:
A rule that disallows using shared variables in fibers,
which are mutated during iterations.

In most cases it leads to unexpected behaviour and is undesired.

For example, having this example:

```
n = 0
channel = Channel(Int32).new

while n < 3
  n = n + 1
  spawn { channel.send n }
end

3.times { puts channel.receive } # => # 3, 3, 3
```

The problem is there is only one shared between fibers variable `n`
and when `channel.receive` is executed its value is `3`.

To solve this, the code above needs to be rewritten to the following:

```
n = 0
channel = Channel(Int32).new

while n < 3
  n = n + 1
  m = n
  spawn do { channel.send m }
end

3.times { puts channel.receive } # => # 1, 2, 3
```

This rule is able to find the shared variables between fibers, which are mutated
during iterations. So it reports the issue on the first sample and passes on
the second one.

There are also other techniques to solve the problem above which are
[officially documented](https://crystal-lang.org/reference/guides/concurrency.html)

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/SharedVarInFiber:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows using shared variables in fibers, which are mutated during iterations.

```
    def test(source)
    end
  end
end

MyRule.parsed_doc # => "This is a test rule.\nDoes nothing."
```

  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)

from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
if scope.spawn_block?
else
  return
end
scope.references.each do |ref|
  if (variable = scope.find_variable(ref.name)).nil?
    next
  end
  if (variable.scope == scope) || !(mutated_in_loop?(variable))
    next
  end
  issue_for(ref.node, MSG % variable.name)
end

types.name: SpecEqWithBoolOrNilLiteral
types.doc:
Reports `eq(true|false|nil)` expectations in specs.

This is considered bad:

```
it "works" do
  foo.is_a?(String).should eq true
  foo.is_a?(Int32).should eq false
  foo.as?(Symbol).should eq nil
end
```

And it should be written as the following:

```
it "works" do
  foo.is_a?(String).should be_true
  foo.is_a?(Int32).should be_false
  foo.as?(Symbol).should be_nil
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/SpecEqWithBoolOrNilLiteral:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: Reports eq(true|false|nil) expectations in specs.

def.name: new
def.body:
if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
if node.name == "should"
else
  return
end
if node.block.nil? && (node.args.size == 1)
else
  return
end
if (matcher = node.args.first).is_a?(Crystal::Call)
else
  return
end
if matcher.name == "eq"
else
  return
end
if matcher.block.nil? && (matcher.args.size == 1)
else
  return
end
replacement = case arg = matcher.args.first
when Crystal::BoolLiteral
  arg.value ? "be_true" : "be_false"
when Crystal::NilLiteral
  "be_nil"
end
if replacement
else
  return
end
issue_for(matcher, MSG % {replacement, matcher.to_s}) do |corrector|
  corrector.replace(matcher, replacement)
end

def.name: new

  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)

from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

instance_methods.doc: TODO: fix the assumption that *source.path* contains relative path
instance_methods.summary: TODO fix the assumption that source.path contains relative path

def.name: test
def.body:
path_ = Path[source.path].to_posix
name = path_.stem
path = path_.to_s
if path.starts_with?("spec/")
else
  return
end
if path.ends_with?(".cr")
else
  return
end
if name.ends_with?("_spec")
  return
end
ignored_dirs.each do |substr|
  if path.starts_with?("#{substr}/")
    return
  end
end
if name.in?(ignored_filenames)
  return
end
expected = "#{name}_spec"
issue_for(LOCATION, MSG % {expected, name}) do
  new_path = path_.sibling(expected + path_.extension)
  FileUtils.mv(path, new_path)
end

types.name: SpecFocus
types.doc:
Checks if specs are focused.

In specs `focus: true` is mainly used to focus on a spec
item locally during development. However, if such change
is committed, it silently runs only focused spec on all
other environment, which is undesired.

This is considered bad:

```
describe MyClass, focus: true do
end

describe ".new", focus: true do
end

context "my context", focus: true do
end

it "works", focus: true do
end
```

And it should be written as the following:

```
describe MyClass do
end

describe ".new" do
end

context "my context" do
end

it "works" do
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/SpecFocus:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: Checks if specs are focused.


types.name: Syntax
types.doc:
A rule that reports invalid Crystal syntax.

For example, this syntax is invalid:

```
def hello
  do_something
rescue Exception => e
end
```

And should be properly written:

```
def hello
  do_something
rescue e : Exception
end
```

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Use a block variant of `rescue` to filter by the exception type"

types.doc:
A rule that prohibits the misconception about how trailing `rescue` statements work,
preventing Paths (exception class names or otherwise) from being used as the
trailing value. The value after the trailing `rescue` statement is the value
to use if an exception occurs, not the exception class to rescue from.

For example, this is considered invalid - if an exception occurs,
`response` will be assigned with the value of `IO::Error` instead of `nil`:

```
response = HTTP::Client.get("http://www.example.com") rescue IO::Error
```

And should instead be written as this in order to capture only `IO::Error` exceptions:

```
response = begin
  HTTP::Client.get("http://www.example.com")
rescue IO::Error
  "default value"
end
```

Or to rescue all exceptions (instead of just `IO::Error`):

```
response = HTTP::Client.get("http://www.example.com") rescue "default value"
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/TrailingRescueException:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that prohibits the misconception about how trailing rescue statements work, preventing Paths (exception class names or otherwise) from being used as the trailing value.

instance_methods.name: test
instance_methods.doc:
This method is designed to test the source passed in. If source has issues
that are tested by this rule, it should add an issue.

By default it uses a node visitor to traverse all the nodes in the source.

NOTE: Must be overridden for other type of rules.
instance_methods.summary: This method is designed to test the source passed in.

def.name: test
def.body:
begin
  typos = typos_from(source)
  typos.try(&.each do |typo|
    corrections = typo.corrections
    message = MSG % {typo.typo, corrections.map do |correction|
      "`#{correction}`"
    end.join(" | ")}
    if corrections.size == 1
      issue_for(typo.location, typo.end_location, message) do |corrector|
        corrector.replace(typo.location, typo.end_location, corrections.first)
      end
    else
      issue_for(typo.location, typo.end_location, message)
    end
  end)
rescue ex
  if fail_on_error?
    raise(ex)
  end
end

def.name: parse
def.body:
issue = JSON.parse(str)
if issue["type"] == "typo"
else
  return
end
typo = issue["typo"].as_s
corrections = issue["corrections"].as_a.map(&.as_s)
if typo.empty? || corrections.empty?
  return
end
line_no = issue["line_num"].as_i
col_no = issue["byte_offset"].as_i + 1
end_col_no = (col_no + typo.size) - 1
new(typo, corrections, {line_no, col_no}, {line_no, end_col_no})

constructors.name: new
constructors.args_string: (typo : String, corrections : Array(String), location : Tuple(Int32, Int32), end_location : Tuple(Int32, Int32))
constructors.args_html: (typo : String, corrections : Array(String), location : Tuple(Int32, Int32), end_location : Tuple(Int32, Int32))

def.name: new
def.body:
_ = allocate
_.initialize(typo, corrections, location, end_location)
if _.responds_to?(:finalize)
  ::GC.add_finalizer(_)
end
_

types.name: UnneededDisableDirective
types.doc:
A rule that reports unneeded disable directives.
For example, this is considered invalid:

```
# ameba:disable Style/PredicateName
def comment?
  do_something
end
```

As the predicate name is correct and the comment directive does not
have any effect, the snippet should be written as the following:

```
def comment?
  do_something
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnneededDisableDirective:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that reports unneeded disable directives.

def.name: new
def.body:
if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
(Tokenizer.new(source)).run do |token|
  if token.type.comment?
  else
    next
  end
  if directive = source.parse_inline_directive(token.value.to_s)
  else
    next
  end
  if names = unneeded_disables(source, directive, token.location)
  else
    next
  end
  if names.empty?
    next
  end
  token_location = {token.location, token.location.adjust(column_number: token.value.to_s.size - 1)}
  issue_for(*token_location, MSG % (names.join(", ")))
end

types.name: UnreachableCode
types.doc:
A rule that reports unreachable code.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
def method(a)
  return 42
  a + 1
end
```

```
a = 1
loop do
  break
  a += 1
end
```

And has to be written as the following:

```
def method(a)
  return 42 if a == 0
  a + 1
end
```

```
a = 1
loop do
  break a > 3
  a += 1
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnreachableCode:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that reports unreachable code.

types.name: UnusedBlockArgument

constants.name: MSG_UNUSED
constants.value: "Unused block argument `%1$s`. If it's necessary, use `_%1$s` as an argument name to indicate that it won't be used."

constants.name: MSG_YIELDED
constants.value: "Use `&` as an argument name to indicate that it won't be referenced."

types.doc:
A rule that reports unused block arguments.
For example, this is considered invalid:

```
def foo(a, b, &block)
  a + b
end

def bar(&block)
  yield 42
end
```

and should be written as:

```
def foo(a, b, &_block)
  a + b
end

def bar(&)
  yield 42
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnusedBlockArgument:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that reports unused block arguments.

constructors.doc:

For example, this is considered invalid:


def.name: new
def.body:
if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
if node.abstract?
  return
end
if block_arg = node.block_arg
else
  return
end
if block_arg = scope.arguments.find() do |__arg0|
  __arg0.node == block_arg
end
else
  return
end
if block_arg.anonymous?
  return
end
if scope.references?(block_arg.variable)
  return
end
location = block_arg.node.location
end_location = location.try(&.adjust(column_number: block_arg.name.size - 1))
case
when scope.yields?
  if location && end_location
    issue_for(location, end_location, MSG_YIELDED) do |corrector|
      corrector.remove(location, end_location)
    end
  else
    issue_for(block_arg.node, MSG_YIELDED)
  end
when !block_arg.ignored?
  if location && end_location
    issue_for(location, end_location, MSG_UNUSED % block_arg.name) do |corrector|
      corrector.insert_before(location, '_')
    end
  else
    issue_for(block_arg.node, MSG_UNUSED % block_arg.name)
  end
end

types.name: UnusedClassVariableAccess

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Value from class variable access is unused"

types.doc:
A rule that disallows unused class variable access.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
class MyClass
  @@my_var : String = "hello"

  @@my_var

  def hello : String
    @@my_var

    "hello, world!"
  end
end
```

And these are considered valid:

```
class MyClass
  @@my_var : String = "hello"

  @@my_other_var = @@my_var

  def hello : String
    return @@my_var if @@my_var == "hello"

    "hello, world!"
  end
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnusedClassVariableAccess:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows unused class variable access.

types.name: UnusedComparison
types.doc:
A rule that disallows unused comparisons.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
a = obj.method do |x|
  x == 1 # => Comparison operation has no effect
  puts x
end

b = if a >= 0
      c < 1 # => Comparison operation has no effect
      "hello world"
    end
```

And these are considered valid:

```
a = obj.method do |x|
  x == 1
end

b = if a >= 0 &&
       c < 1
      "hello world"
    end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnusedComparison:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows unused comparisons.

A rule that disallows unused generics or unions (`String?`, `StaticArray(Int32, 10)`, etc).

```
end
```

```
a : Int32 = 10

alias MyType = Float64 | StaticArray(Float64, 10)

  0.1
end
```

```
Lint/UnusedGenericOrUnion:
```

def.name: test

types.doc:

For example, these are considered invalid:

```

else
  false
end

    false
  end

  true
end
```

And these are considered valid:

```
a = 1234_f32

def method
  if guard?
    false
  else
    true
  end
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnusedLiteral:
  Enabled: true
```

types.name: UnusedLocalVariableAccess

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Value from local variable access is unused"

types.doc:
A rule that disallows unused local variable access.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
a = 1
b = "2"
c = :3

case method_call
when Int32
  a
when String
  b
else
  c
end

def hello(name)
  if name.size < 10
    name
  end

  name[...10]
end
```

And these are considered valid:

```
a = 1
b = "2"
c = :3

d = case method_call
    when Int32
      a
    when String
      b
    else
      c
    end

def hello(name)
  if name.size < 10
    return name
  end

  name[...10]
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UnusedLocalVariableAccess:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows unused local variable access.

types.name: UselessAssign
types.doc:
A rule that disallows useless assignments.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
def method
  var = 1
  do_something
end
```

And has to be written as the following:

```
def method
  var = 1
  do_something(var)
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UselessAssign:
  Enabled: true
  ExcludeTypeDeclarations: false
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows useless assignments.

def.name: new
def.body:
if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
if scope.lib_def?(check_outer_scopes: true)
  return
end
scope.variables.each do |var|
  if (var.ignored? || var.used_in_macro?) || var.captured_by_block?
    next
  end
  if exclude_type_declarations? && (scope.assigns_type_dec?(var.name))
    next
  end
  var.assignments.each do |assign|
    check_assignment(source, assign, var)
  end
end

types.name: UselessConditionInWhen
types.doc:
A rule that disallows useless conditions in `when` clause
where it is guaranteed to always return the same result.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
case
when utc?
  io << " UTC"
when local?
  Format.new(" %:z").format(self, io) if local?
end
```

And has to be written as the following:

```
case
when utc?
  io << " UTC"
when local?
  Format.new(" %:z").format(self, io)
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Lint/UselessConditionInWhen:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that disallows useless conditions in when clause where it is guaranteed to always return the same result.

types.name: AccessorMethodName
types.doc:
A rule that makes sure that accessor methods are named properly.

Favour this:

```
class Foo
  def user
    @user
  end

  def user=(value)
    @user = value
  end
end
```

Over this:

```
class Foo
  def get_user
    @user
  end

  def set_user(value)
    @user = value
  end
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Naming/AccessorMethodName:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: A rule that makes sure that accessor methods are named properly.

```
end
```

  check_issue(source, arg, prefer_name_location: true)
  check_symbol_literal(source, arg.default_value)
end

types.name: BinaryOperatorParameterName

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "When defining the `%s` operator, name its argument `other`"

types.doc:
A rule that enforces that certain binary operator methods have
their sole parameter named `other`.

For example, this is considered valid:

```
class Money
  def +(other)
  end
end
```

And this is invalid parameter name:

```
class Money
  def +(amount)
  end
end
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Naming/BinaryOperatorParameterName:
  Enabled: true
  ExcludedOperators: ["[]", "[]?", "[]=", "<<", ">>", "=~", "!~"]
```
types.summary: A rule that enforces that certain binary operator methods have their sole parameter named other.

def.name: new

  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
name = node.name
if (name == "->") || (name.in?(excluded_operators))
  return
end
if name.chars.any?(&.alphanumeric?)
  return
end
if node.args.size == 1
else
  return
end
if (arg = node.args.first).name == "other"
  return
end
issue_for(arg, MSG % name)

```
  AllowedNames: [e, i, j, k, v, x, y, ex, io, ws, op, tx, id, ip, k1, k2, v1, v2]
```

types.name: ConstantNames
types.doc:
A rule that enforces constant names to be in screaming case.

For example, these constant names are considered valid:

```
LUCKY_NUMBERS     = [3, 7, 11]
DOCUMENTATION_URL = "http://crystal-lang.org/docs"
```

And these are invalid names:

```
myBadConstant = 1
Wrong_NAME = 2
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Naming/ConstantNames:
```

def.name: new

if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
each_call_node(node) do |exp|
  if exp.name.in?(CALL_NAMES)
  else
    next
  end
  exp.args.each do |arg|
    name_node, is_bool = case arg
    when Crystal::Assign
      {arg.target, arg.value.is_a?(Crystal::BoolLiteral)}
    when Crystal::TypeDeclaration
      {arg.var, path_named?(arg.declared_type, "Bool")}
    else
      {nil, false}
    end
    if name_node && is_bool
      issue_for(name_node, MSG % {exp.name, name_node})
    end
  end
end

types.name: RescuedExceptionsVariableName

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Disallowed variable name, use one of these instead: '%s'"

types.doc:
A rule that makes sure that rescued exceptions variables are named as expected.

For example, these are considered valid:

    def foo
      # potentially raising computations
    rescue e
      Log.error(exception: e) { "Error" }
    end

And these are invalid variable names:

    def foo
      # potentially raising computations
    rescue wtf
      Log.error(exception: wtf) { "Error" }
    end

YAML configuration example:

```
Naming/RescuedExceptionsVariableName:
  Enabled: true
  AllowedNames: [e, ex, exception, error]
```
types.summary: A rule that makes sure that rescued exceptions variables are named as expected.

def.name: test
def.body:
node.rescues.try(&.each do |rescue_node|
  if valid_name?(rescue_node.name)

  message = allowed_names.size == 1 ? MSG_SINGULAR : MSG

types.name: AnyAfterFilter
types.doc:
This rule is used to identify usage of `any?` calls that follow filters.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
[1, 2, 3].select { |e| e > 2 }.any?
[1, 2, 3].reject { |e| e >= 2 }.any?
```

And it should be written as this:

```
[1, 2, 3].any? { |e| e > 2 }
[1, 2, 3].any? { |e| e < 2 }
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Performance/AnyAfterFilter:
  Enabled: true
  FilterNames:
    - select
    - reject
```
types.summary: This rule is used to identify usage of any? calls that follow filters.

types.name: AnyInsteadOfEmpty
types.doc:
This rule is used to identify usage of arg-less `Enumerable#any?` calls.

Using `Enumerable#any?` instead of `Enumerable#empty?` might lead to an
unexpected results (like `[nil, false].any? # => false`). In some cases
it also might be less efficient, since it iterates until the block will
return a _truthy_ value, instead of just checking if there's at least
one value present.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
[1, 2, 3].any?
```

And it should be written as this:

```
![1, 2, 3].empty?
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Performance/AnyInsteadOfEmpty:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: This rule is used to identify usage of arg-less Enumerable#any? calls.

types.name: ChainedCallWithNoBang

constants.name: ALLOCATING_METHOD_NAMES
constants.doc: All these methods allocate a new object
constants.summary: All these methods allocate a new object

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Use bang method variant `%s!` after chained `%s` call"

types.doc:
This rule is used to identify usage of chained calls not utilizing
the bang method variants.

For example, this is considered inefficient:

```
names = %w[Alice Bob]
chars = names
  .flat_map(&.chars)
  .uniq
  .sort
```

And can be written as this:

```
names = %w[Alice Bob]
chars = names
  .flat_map(&.chars)
  .uniq!
  .sort!
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Performance/ChainedCallWithNoBang:
  Enabled: true
  CallNames:
    - uniq
    - unstable_sort
    - sort
    - sort_by
    - shuffle
    - reverse
```
types.summary: This rule is used to identify usage of chained calls not utilizing the bang method variants.

```
  .flat_map(&.chars)
  .uniq
  .sort
```

And can be written as this:

```
names = %w[Alice Bob]
chars = names
  .flat_map(&.chars)
  .uniq!
  .sort!
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Performance/ChainedCallWithNoBang:
  Enabled: true
  CallNames:
    - uniq
    - unstable_sort
    - sort
    - sort_by
    - shuffle
    - reverse
```
constructors.summary: This rule is used to identify usage of chained calls not utilizing the bang method variants.

def.name: test
def.body:
if (obj = node.obj).is_a?(Crystal::Call)
else
  return
end
if node.name.in?(call_names)
else
  return
end
if (obj.name.in?(call_names)) || (obj.name.in?(ALLOCATING_METHOD_NAMES))
else
  return
end
if end_location = name_end_location(node)
  issue_for(node, MSG % {node.name, obj.name}, prefer_name_location: true) do |corrector|
    corrector.insert_after(end_location, '!')
  end
else
  issue_for(node, MSG % {node.name, obj.name}, prefer_name_location: true)
end

types.name: ExcessiveAllocations

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Use `%s {...}` instead of `%s.each {...}` to avoid excessive allocation"

types.doc:
This rule is used to identify excessive collection allocations,
that can be avoided by using `each_<member>` instead of `<collection>.each`.

For example, this is considered inefficient:

```
"Alice".chars.each { |c| puts c }
"Alice\nBob".lines.each { |l| puts l }
```

And can be written as this:

```
"Alice".each_char { |c| puts c }
"Alice\nBob".each_line { |l| puts l }
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Performance/ExcessiveAllocations:
  Enabled: true
  CallNames:
    codepoints: each_codepoint
    graphemes: each_grapheme
    chars: each_char
    lines: each_line
```
types.summary: This rule is used to identify excessive collection allocations, that can be avoided by using each_<member> instead of <collection>.each.

types.name: FirstLastAfterFilter
types.doc:
This rule is used to identify usage of `first/last/first?/last?` calls that follow filters.

For example, this is considered inefficient:

```
[-1, 0, 1, 2].select { |e| e > 0 }.first?
[-1, 0, 1, 2].select { |e| e > 0 }.last?
```

And can be written as this:

```
[-1, 0, 1, 2].find { |e| e > 0 }
[-1, 0, 1, 2].reverse_each.find { |e| e > 0 }
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Performance/FirstLastAfterFilter
  Enabled: true
  FilterNames:
    - select
```
types.summary: This rule is used to identify usage of first/last/first?/last? calls that follow filters.

types.name: MinMaxAfterMap
types.doc:
This rule is used to identify usage of `min/max/minmax` calls that follow `map`.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
%w[Alice Bob].map(&.size).min
%w[Alice Bob].map(&.size).max
%w[Alice Bob].map(&.size).minmax
```

And it should be written as this:

```
%w[Alice Bob].min_of(&.size)
%w[Alice Bob].max_of(&.size)
%w[Alice Bob].minmax_of(&.size)
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Performance/MinMaxAfterMap:
  Enabled: true
```

def.name: new
def.body:
if (raw = config.try(&.raw)).is_a?(Hash)
  yaml = raw[rule_name]?.try(&.to_yaml)
end
from_yaml(yaml || "{}")

def.name: test
def.body:
if ((node.name.in?(CALL_NAMES)) && node.block.nil?) && node.args.empty?
else
  return
end
if (obj = node.obj) && obj.is_a?(Crystal::Call)
else
  return
end
if ((obj.name == "map") && obj.block) && obj.args.empty?
else
  return
end
if name_location = name_location(obj)
else
  return
end
if end_location = name_end_location(node)
else
  return
end
of_name = node.name.sub(/(.+?)(\?)?$/, "\\1_of\\2")
message = MSG % {of_name, node.name}
issue_for(name_location, end_location, message) do |corrector|
  if node_name_location = name_location(node)
  else
    next
  end
  corrector.replace(name_location, name_location.adjust(column_number: {{ "map".size - 1 }}), of_name)
  corrector.remove(node_name_location.adjust(column_number: -1), end_location)
end

types.name: SizeAfterFilter
types.doc:
This rule is used to identify usage of `size` calls that follow filter.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
[1, 2, 3].select { |e| e > 2 }.size
[1, 2, 3].reject { |e| e < 2 }.size
[1, 2, 3].select(&.< 2).size
[0, 1, 2].select(&.zero?).size
[0, 1, 2].reject(&.zero?).size
```

And it should be written as this:

```
[1, 2, 3].count { |e| e > 2 }
[1, 2, 3].count { |e| e >= 2 }
[1, 2, 3].count(&.< 2)
[0, 1, 2].count(&.zero?)
[0, 1, 2].count(&.!= 0)
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Performance/SizeAfterFilter:
  Enabled: true
  FilterNames:
    - select
    - reject
```
types.summary: This rule is used to identify usage of size calls that follow filter.


types.name: GuardClause

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Use a guard clause (`%s`) instead of wrapping the code inside a conditional expression."

types.doc:
Use a guard clause instead of wrapping the code inside a conditional
expression

```
# bad
def test
  if something
    work
  end
end

# good
def test
  return unless something

  work
end

# also good
def test
  work if something
end

# bad
if something
  raise "exception"
else
  ok
end

# good
raise "exception" if something
ok

# bad
if something
  foo || raise("exception")
else
  ok
end

# good
foo || raise("exception") if something
ok
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/GuardClause:
  Enabled: true
```
types.summary: Use a guard clause instead of wrapping the code inside a conditional expression

```
# bad
def test
  if something
    work
  end
end

# good
def test
  return unless something

  work
end

# also good
def test
  work if something
end

# bad
if something
  raise "exception"
else
  ok
end

# good
raise "exception" if something
ok

# bad
if something
  foo || raise("exception")
else
  ok
end

# good
foo || raise("exception") if something
ok
```

YAML configuration example:

```
Style/GuardClause:
  Enabled: true
```
constructors.summary: Use a guard clause instead of wrapping the code inside a conditional expression

def.body:
final_expression = if (body = node.body).is_a?(Crystal::Expressions)
  body.last
else
  body
end
case final_expression
when Crystal::If, Crystal::Unless
  check_ending_if(source, final_expression)

def.name: test
def.body:
if accepted_form?(source, node, ending: false)
  return
end
case
when guard_clause = guard_clause(node.then)
  parent, conditional_keyword = node.then, keyword(node)
when guard_clause = guard_clause(node.else)
  parent, conditional_keyword = node.else, opposite_keyword(node)
end
if (guard_clause && parent) && conditional_keyword
else
  return
end
guard_clause_source = guard_clause_source(source, guard_clause, parent)
report_issue(source, node, guard_clause_source, conditional_keyword)

types.name: HeredocIndent

constants.name: MSG
constants.value: "Heredoc body should be indented by %s spaces"

types.doc:
A rule that enforces _Heredoc_ bodies be indented one level above the indentation of the
line they're used on.

For example, this is considered invalid:

```
<<-HERERDOC
  hello world
HEREDOC

  <<-HERERDOC
hello world
HEREDOC
```

And should be written as:

```
<<-HERERDOC
    hello world
  HEREDOC

  <<-HERERDOC
    hello world
    HEREDOC
```

The `IndentBy` configuration option changes the enforced indentation level of the _heredoc_.

```
Style/HeredocIndent:
  Enabled: true
  IndentBy: 2
```
types.summary: A rule that enforces Heredoc bodies be indented one level above the indentation of the line they're used on.

else
